snippet: Under a bill signed last week, New York City will study whether it is feasible to generate hydroelectric power from the city’s water supply.
abstract: Jim Dwyer About New York column on proposition that water traveling to New York City's population from Upstate New York could also be used to drive turbines and produce electricity; asserts that if theory proves viable, hydroelectric power harvested from city's water mains could be a renewable, and predictable, source of carbon-free power. (M)
lead_paragraph: The water that comes out of taps in New York City runs downhill 125 miles from the Catskill Mountains, every last drop the product of 19th-century genius and scheming that made the modern metropolis possible. Now comes a new proposition for what is arguably the world's greatest urban water system: people are trying to figure out if, on its way to your shower, the water can also drive turbines and make electricity.

headline.main: Seeing Source Of Electricity In Water Pipes
